---
title: "redis-ca-invalid.yml"
---

## High-level description
This YAML configuration file defines settings for a cache system using Redis as the backend. It includes options for enabling the cache, specifying the backend type, setting a Time-To-Live (TTL) value, and configuring Redis-specific options such as CA certificate details.

## Symbols

### `cache`
#### Description
The root configuration object for the cache system.

#### Inputs
| Name | Type | Description |
|:-----|:-----|:------------|
| enabled | boolean | Determines whether the cache is enabled or not |
| backend | string | Specifies the cache backend to be used (in this case, "redis") |
| ttl | duration | Sets the Time-To-Live for cached items |
| redis | object | Contains Redis-specific configuration options |

### `redis`
#### Description
A nested configuration object within `cache` that specifies Redis-specific settings.

#### Inputs
| Name | Type | Description |
|:-----|:-----|:------------|
| ca_cert_bytes | string | Contains the CA certificate content as a multi-line string |
| ca_cert_path | string | Specifies the file path to the CA certificate |

## Configuration
| Option | Type | Default | Description |
|:-------|:-----|:--------|:------------|
| cache.enabled | boolean | true | Enables or disables the cache system |
| cache.backend | string | "redis" | Specifies Redis as the cache backend |
| cache.ttl | duration | "60s" | Sets the Time-To-Live for cached items to 60 seconds |
| cache.redis.ca_cert_bytes | string | "pemblock" | Placeholder for the CA certificate content |
| cache.redis.ca_cert_path | string | "internal/config/testdata/ca.pem" | File path to the CA certificate |

## Notes
1. The file name "redis-ca-invalid.yml" suggests that this configuration might be used for testing invalid CA certificate scenarios.
2. The `ca_cert_bytes` field contains a placeholder value "pemblock", which would typically be replaced with an actual PEM-encoded CA certificate in a real configuration.
3. The `ca_cert_path` points to a file named "ca.pem" in the "internal/config/testdata/" directory, which is likely used for testing purposes.
4. The TTL of 60 seconds (60s) is a relatively short duration, which might be suitable for testing or for data that changes frequently.

This configuration file appears to be part of a test suite, specifically designed to test how the system handles invalid or misconfigured CA certificates for Redis connections.
